title: What to Put in Your Spring Forage Mix

tasks.task: Discussing Spring Cover Crop Forage Options
subtasks: Accessing the smart mix calculator online
Entering Nathan's hometown zip code for regional climate data
Selecting a general mix for a spring forage rather than a custom one
Choosing a bagging option for a drilled cover (seeding method)
Setting the next cash crop as wheat (considering time constraints)
Selecting a single goal for the mix (supplemental grazing)
Adding legumes to the mix (spring forage peas and crimson clover)
Adding grasses (spring oats and annual rye)
Including brassicas (kale and collards)
Considering mycorrhizal benefits and pollinator attraction
Adjusting seeding rates for desired tonnage and cost trade-offs
Tailoring the mix for a rain-fed environment (modifying seeding rates)
Finalizing the mix composition (e.g., pounds per acre of each species)

tasks.task: Customizing the mix for specific conditions
subtasks: Selecting appropriate species based on regional factors (e.g., drought potential)
Considering soil fertility and moisture levels
Balancing tonnage and cost through adjusted seeding rates
Evaluating the mix's potential for hay production during drought recovery
Preparing the field for planting (e.g., tillage, soil preparation)
Drilling the cover crop seeds at the calculated rates
Ensuring proper coverage and seed-to-soil contact
Managing the forage for supplemental grazing (e.g., timing, rotational grazing)
Assessing the mix’s performance for future cash crop benefits (e.g., organic matter, pest suppression)
